attributes.title: Hasbro's Financials Weren't That Bad
summary: Hasbro's share price doesn't really deserve to be beaten after very decent Q2 (and H1) results.
The adjusted free cash flow was more than 40% higher compared to the first semester of last year.
I expect Hasbro to fully repay a $350M note maturing in 2017. This will reduce the interest expenses by $22M per year, and boost the free cash flow results.
Hasbro is trading at a free cash flow yield of 5.5% which isn't very expensive, but I'd like to try to buy the stock at a lower price.

attributes.content:
Introduction

Hasbro's (NASDAQ:HAS) share price nosedived when the company published its financial results. I'm not sure why the market thought the company's performance was abysmal, as Hasbro's net income and free cash flow increased compared to the same period last year. Perhaps the expectations were too high, but does that mean Hasbro also is an uninteresting investment right now?

HAS data by YCharts

Was the market expecting unrealistic things? The income and cash flows are very decent

Sometimes it's difficult to realize and understand what the market really wants. All in all, Hasbro's second quarter was really decent (and that's actually an understatement) with a revenue increase of approximately 10% to $879M. Not only is this really good, it also takes a negative impact from a changing foreign exchange situation into account, which reduced the revenue by almost $18% (or 2%).

Source: SEC filings

It's pretty normal to see the corresponding production costs and expenses increasing as well, but fortunately these didn't increase at a faster rate than the revenue, and Hasbro's operating margin remained actually increased a little bit to 9.7%, for an operating income of almost $85M (which is almost exactly the same result as in the first quarter of the financial year! The net income attributable to Hasbro's shareholders was $52.1M, resulting in an EPS of $0.42 for the quarter, and $0.80 for the first semester. This H1 result is approximately 45% higher than what has been achieved in H1 2015, despite a 2% increase in the company's share count.

Source: SEC filings

A net profit of $101M is really great, but does this result hold up on the cash flow front as well? It sure looks like it, considering the operating cash flow was $269M on a non-adjusted basis. That's really strong, considering the contribution from changes in its working capital was approximately 25% lower than the previous year. This allowed Hasbro to generate an adjusted operating cash flow of $224M and an adjusted free cash flow of $158M in the first half of the current financial year (compared to just $110M in H1 FY 2015).

Even though Hasbro loves to treat its shareholders, it's not spending more than it can afford

So, the net income increased by 45%, whilst the adjusted free cash flow increased by 44%, yet the company's share price got hit by a high single digit percentage price drop. But why?

Source: company presentation, via Seeking Alpha

We all know the second half of the year is the strongest season for Hasbro (last year, the company generated a total adjusted free cash flow of $430M in the second half of the year), and there isn't really any reason to think this year will be different. Sure, the economic future looks a bit more shaky now with all the Brexit votes and coup d'état's in the world, but keep in mind Hasbro starts the second half of the year with a $48M head start compared to its results in the previous financial year. Additionally, the impact of Star Wars will continue to decrease, but we have always known the majority of the Star Wars-related revenue wouldn't be recurring. Besides, every (other) year a new hype pops up, so Hasbro should be able to deal with lower revenues from the Star Wars division.

That being said, I also like the way how Hasbro is allocating its free cash flow. Most companies are currently in a 'repurchase race' and try to reduce their share count no matter what, but Hasbro is playing a more strategic game.

HAS Cash from Operations (Annual) data by YCharts

Let's now assume the company's full-year free cash flow will be exactly the same as last year ($540M, despite the strong start of the year). This means that after paying the approximately $250M in dividends, Hasbro will have $290M available for a variety of purposes. Most companies tend to borrow cash to buy back more stock than they can actually afford, but Hasbro is very disciplined.

It did spend quite a bit of cash on buybacks (almost $160M, to repurchase almost 0.75M shares), but Hasbro also repaid $160M of debt from its existing cash position, and that's an important factor. Whilst most companies are increasing the net debt exactly to fund their repurchase programs, Hasbro is reducing its gross debt, which will reduce its interest expenses (see later).

Let's take a step back and have another look at Hasbro's income statement. The total interest expense in the first half of the year was approximately $48M (vs $49M in H1 FY 2015), so it's actually in Hasbro's interest to reduce the gross debt as fast as possible as this will have a huge impact on the interest bill.

Investment thesis

Hasbro now has a free cash flow yield of approximately 5-5.5% (depending on its H2 results) and whilst that's not cheap, it's the price you pay for a strong cash flowing company with a decent balance sheet in this ZIRP/NIRP society.

Keep in mind Hasbro's debt will only gradually decrease as the maturity date of its notes has been spread out over time (see the previous image). However, should Hasbro decide to repay the bond maturing in 2017 (which it definitely should do, considering it's high-cost debt and Hasbro has plenty of cash to repay the note), its interest expenses will decrease by $22M per year, boosting the free cash flow by $15M…

I just wish the company was able to repay a part of its remaining debt as well, but that will be quite difficult considering the premium Hasbro would have to pay. That being said, simply repaying the 2017 bond will increase the free cash flow by 12 cents per share, and this confirms my impression the market shouldn't really have punished Hasbro for its financial results. The current 'crash' will increase the volatility in the option market, and I might write an out of the money put option to try to get an initial long position at a lower price.
